content: The Dow Jones industrials rose 0.5% in late-afternoon trading and look poised for a fifth straight advance in six sessions Tuesday, even as U.S. interest rates climbed sharply. Superregional banks took the lead, rising 1.8% as a group.X But certain medical names also flexed strength; stocks in IBD's Medical-Research Equipment/Services and Medical-Diversified industry groups also romped higher with similar-sized gains.But the top industry group performance belongs to oil and gas royalty trusts (up 2.3%) and Canadian oil explorers (up 2.1%) with roughly an hour to go in the regular session. U.S. crude oil prices continue to swing back up after a sell-off on Jan. 5, with near-term futures up 1.4% to $62.60 a barrel, the highest level since 2015.The Nasdaq composite lagged, rising 0.2%; the S&P 500 gained 0.3% despite another harsh sell-off in certain utility stocks, particularly in water supply and diversified utilities.The Dow utility average dropped 0.9%; the Dow transports rallied 0.3%, stretching its year-to-date gain to 3.9%.Despite the mild gains, breadth was slightly negative on the NYSE, as losing stocks edged winners by more than 200 issues. On the Nasdaq, winners and losers were roughly equal. Volume is running mildly higher vs. the same time on both main exchanges.SVB Financial (SIVB), a Silicon Valley-based lender, is part of IBD's super regional banking industry group, and shares in the stock market today added nearly 2% to 248.14 and new highs.SVB Financial entered Leaderboard on Nov. 30, trading around 227 at the time. The stock is now extended after clearing a narrow pullback that offered an extra entry point at 223.92.The ideal buy point was triggered on Oct. 26, when the stock lifted past a 191.48 entry in a saucer with handle. The next day, shares soared more than 12% in vigorous volume on an excellent third quarter (earnings up 32% to $2.79 a share, revenue up 22% to $544 million).SVB is one of just three superregionals that sport a Composite Rating on IBD Stock Checkup of 90 or higher. The other two are Comerica (CMA) (91 Comp) and Huntington Bancshares (HBAN) (90).Target (TGT), up nearly 3% to 69.48 in fast turnover,  has formed a bottoming base and could create a new buy point if resistance remains near 70.The discount retailing titan, which reported upbeat same-store sales growth of 3.4% for November and December combined, offered aggressive buy points at both 63.20 and 63.72 within its bottoming base, a bullish pattern after a near-cataclysmic decline.PayPal (PYPL) broke out of a narrow flat base at 79.48 but is stalling. The digital payments expert got as high as 80.39 intraday before gains melted to just 0.4%. But the stock gave follow-on entry points in December as it rebounded back above the 50-day moving average.Meanwhile, Bitcoin-related ETFs traded rather calmly.The Bitcoin Investment Trust (GBTC) lost just 1.5% to 2,172.60. Quiet price moves in low volume are ideal right now for the hot alternative currency-tracking vehicle. The 50-day moving average continues to rise and play catch-up.Money continued to flow out of U.S. government bonds. The fresh cash may find its way into other asset classes, including equities and commodities such as industrial metals and crude oil.The yield on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note jumped to 2.54%, its highest so far in 2018 and now just 8 basis points below the March 2017 peak of 2.62%.The yield curve continues to be positive, which encourages lending and economic growth.RELATED:What Is The Flat Base, And How Can It Pump Up Gains In Your Stock Portfolio?Stocks Near A Buy ZoneThe Latest Names In IBD LeaderboardDo You Know This Crucial Chart Pattern For Stock Breakouts?How To Find Outstanding Stocks At The Right Time: Follow A Simple Routine

X Stocks deepened their losses into the close on Wednesday, as the latest accusations against the White House stirred deepening uncertainty in the nation's capital.The Nasdaq sliced 2.6% lower, its worst loss since June. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each lopped off 1.8%, the worst session for both since the Sept. 9 sell-off that followed comments from Federal Reserve officials that all but assured a rate hike that month.Volume roared, up significantly on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges.The trigger appeared to be news reports that notes by former FBI Director James Comey during a February meeting with President Trump, just after National Security Advisor Michael Flynn had resigned, portrayed the president pressing the director to drop the agency's probe of Flynn. Trump fired Comey on May 9. The White House has so far given conflicting reasons for Comey's firing.Markets in Europe carved out sizable losses, with the CAC 40 in Paris ending down 1.6% and Frankfurt's DAX taking a 1.4% loss.Fiber-optic stocks had some of the day's worst losses. Oclaro (OCLR) tanked 9.5% and Lumentum Holdings (LITE) skidded 8%. Finisar (FNSR) unraveled 9% and Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) caved 5.5%.Superregional and investment banks were also hit hard. SVB Financial (SIVB) and SunTrust (STI) shed 6% apiece. So did Morgan Stanley (MS) and Bank of America (BAC). Dow component Goldman Sachs (GS) fell 5%. Huntington Bancshares (HBAN) and Comerica (CMA) dived 6% apiece.Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan (JPM) presented the worst losses among Dow industrials. Apple (AAPL) soured 3%.UnitedHealth Group (UNH) logged the strongest gain among blue chips, up 0.4% despite the U.S. Department of Justice launching its second suit against the Medicare Advantage provider in less than a month, alleging more than $1.1 billion in billing fraud.Colgate Palmolive (CL) squeezed out a 6% gain to lead the S&P 500, after news reports said CEO Ian Cook had said he'd be open to selling the company at $100 per share. The comment, which valued the personal products company near $88 billion, reportedly was made during a conference with institutional investors.Chipmakers scored the worst losses among S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 stocks. Micron Technologies (MU) dived 7% to mark the bottom of both lists. Nvidia (NVDA) also dropped 7%, ending a five-day breakout rally. It's now negative for the week.Among companies reporting quarterly earnings, both Jack in the Box (JACK) and Qiwi (QIWI) rattled off 6% gains. Qiwi pared its early 12% gain to end in buy range above a 20.42 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.RELATED: Earnings Distractions From Trump Crises: Investing Action PlanWhich Three Sectors Are Seeing Gains Despite Market Sell Off?

XFutures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 were slightly lower Wednesday morning in New York, signaling that Tuesday's sell-off heavy losses would continue into Wednesday.Futures for the Dow industrials and S&P 500 index slid about 0.2% vs. fair value, while the Nasdaq 100 lost about 0.3%.On Tuesday, the Nasdaq composite opened at a new high, led by big-cap techs such as Apple (AAPL) (also a Dow component). But market sentiment reversed amid concerns about President Trump's tax cuts: The Nasdaq composite tumbled 1.8%, the S&P 500 index 1.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.1%, the worst losses of the year. The Dow Jones Transportation Average sank 1.9% to its lowest level since late November. Apple, for its part, reversed from a record high to close down 1.15%, below a recent buy point.There's growing concern on Wall Street that Trump's tax cuts and other parts of his pro-growth agenda could be derailed if the ObamaCare replacement bill falters, perhaps in a planned Thursday House vote. The concern is that Congress could get bogged down with health care, especially with a small GOP Senate majority and Trump's low approval ratings.The Dow and other major averages have soared since Election Day on hopes and expectations that the new president and GOP Congress would make good on his promises.That's hitting financial stocks such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Goldman Sachs (GS), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) especially hard.Expectations for Trump's agenda have helped bank stocks especially.Not only did stocks sell off on Tuesday, but Treasury yields continued their sharp decline since the Fed's March 15 decision. Worse for banks, the yield curve has flattened significantly recently.JPMorgan Chase tumbled 2.9% and fellow Dow financial Goldman Sachs lost 3.8%. Bank of America plunged 5.8% and Citigroup 2.6%. All are now below their 50-day moving averages.But it's not just the Wall Street giants. Every one of the Bank-Super Regional members is trading below their 50-day line. (That includes Keycorp (KEY), Huntington Bancshares (HBAN) and Comerica (CMA), the only S&P 500 index members to fall more than BofA.) So are a slew of smaller bank stocks that had been market leaders until recently.New York selling spread to Asia: Japan's Nikkei closed down 2.1%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng 1.1% and China's Shanghai composite 0.5%.In European morning trade, stocks were down nearly 1% in the U.K., France and Germany.RELATED:ObamaCare Repeal Vote Failure Threatens Tax Cuts — And Stock RallyThe 3 Earnings Reports To Watch Today: Investing Action PlanFinancials, Small Caps Rocked As Market Outlook Weakens

The rally in regional banks has moderated, but two ETFs that track the industry are using that pause to refresh their charts.The charts of SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE) and iShares U.S. Regional Banks (IAT) look like twins, the way they've behaved so similarly. Both have pulled back from highs reached at the start of March and are testing the 50-day moving average.With a bit more of a bounce, both exchange traded funds will be in buy areas. At the moment, the support at the 50-day line is not convincing enough. Watch for shares of both to climb at least one more point, and preferably in above-average volume.No chart reader would dispute that both ETFs were in need of a break. They shot up starting in mid-November on a combination of rising interest rates and President Trump's election. Trump and Republicans are trying to ease banking regulations, and higher rates are widening interest margins for banks.While SPDR Regional Banking has 100 stocks, iShares Regional Banks has about half as many.Still, the two portfolios are similar in terms of the largest holdings. PNC Financial Services (PNC), SunTrust Bank (STI), M&T Bank (MTB), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB), Huntington Bancshares (HBAN), KeyCorp (KEY), Regions Financial (RF), Citizens Financial (CFG) and BB&T (BBT) are top-10 holdings in both funds.The two differ in that iShares Regional Banks has a big stake in U.S. Bancorp (USB) (more than 16% of the portfolio) while the superregional bank doesn't even make the SPDR Regional Banking portfolio.The holdings of SPDR Regional Banking are more spread out, with no single stock accounting for more than 4% of the total weighting.With the Federal Reserve expected to increase interest rates by a quarter-point two more times this year, the fundamental backdrop for regional banks is generally favorable. Higher rates tend to widen the margin between interest earned on loans vs. interest paid on deposits.LPL Financial, for example, had this to say: "Steepening yield curve, deregulation, expanded credit access, strong fourth quarter 2016 earnings, and positive revisions are all supportive."But Alastair George, chief strategist at Edison Investment Research, saw an economic warning sign in the banking sector. Big banks JPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) got through the second and final round of the Federal Reserve's annual stress tests unscathed, resulting in a shareholder-returns bonanza shortly after the test results were announced late Wednesday.But Morgan Stanley's (MS) capital plan only got conditional approval, and U.S. segments of Deutsche Bank (DB) and Santander (SAN) failed once againStill, Morgan Stanley said it will move forward with a 33% quarterly dividend hike to 20 cents and a $3.5 billion buyback. JPMorgan OK'd a $10.6 billion buyback but kept its dividend the same. Bank of America announced a $5 billion repurchase program and a 50% payout increase to 7.5 cents. Citigroup will buy back $8.6 billion in stock and raised its payout to 16 cents from 5 cents.Goldman Sachs (GS) didn't give specifics but said its plan included buybacks and a dividend hike. Wells Fargo (WFC)  kept its capital plans unchanged.Morgan Stanley stock were little changed in pre-market trading on the stock market today after rising late Wednesday JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Citigroup climbed 2.4%, Wells Fargo rose and Goldman Sachs all rose fractionally. Deutsche Bank, which the IMF said "poses the greatest risk to the global financial system," sank nearly 4% while Santander fell 2%.Other banks also announced bigger returns to shareholders.The Fed only gave conditional approval to Morgan Stanley's capital plan, in which it projected how it would perform under difficult economic conditions for this year's stress tests. As a result, Morgan must resubmit its capital plan and address broader concerns from the Fed by Dec. 29. If Morgan can't deliver on those promises, the Fed said, its governors "would expect to object" to the resubmitted plan, potentially hindering Morgan's shareholder returns.While the Fed did not technically object to Morgan Stanley's capital plan, the central bank said the company "exhibited material weaknesses in its capital planning process," including in governance, modeling and other safeguards."These weaknesses warrant further near-term attention but do not undermine the quantitative results of the stress tests for the firm," the Fed said, referring to the portion of the tests that quantifies what banks' capital levels would look like under financial turmoil.The Fed said Deutsche Bank and Santander, both of which also had their plans rejected last year, had tightened up some aspects of their capital planning methodology but still struggled with "material unresolved supervisory issues that critically undermine (the) capital planning process."The results follow a pattern of stress-test one-upmanship between the banks, which have been shoring up capital since the financial crisis, and the Fed, which has tried harder each year to catch the banks off-guard in the scenarios posed in the tests.While the banks that passed can move forward with their dividend and buyback hikes, tougher standards on the horizon could keep payouts restrained this year. Fed Governor Daniel Tarullo warned this month that banks in future tests might have to make a "significant increase" in the assets they set aside to cushion against a potential economic crisis.The final round of results from the stress tests -- known as the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, or CCAR -- came after all 33 tested banks last week passed the first round of the evaluation, which quantifies how banks' finances would be affected against a barrage of market shocks.The Fed outlined the economic scenarios for both tests at the beginning of the year. In the weeks that followed, the banks submitted their capital plans, which this year forecast how they would do amid 10% unemployment, negative interest rates on short-term U.S. Treasuries -- among the conditions in the Fed's worst-case scenario.The first round of test results can serve as a preview of sorts to the second, in which the Fed actually indicates whether it accepted, rejected or had any reservations with the banks' capital plans. If it does have an issue, banks could have to temper plans to issue buybacks and boost dividends in order to pass.The second round of tests contains both a quantitative element and qualitative element. The quantitative element measures banks post-stress-test capital levels and whether they could sustain any new dividend and buyback plans. The qualitative element evaluates the soundness of the banks' capital plans and how they were developed.Analysts largely had not anticipated major problems with the banks' stress-test results.

Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS) and Wells Fargo (WFC) and 27 other banks passed the first round of Federal Reserve stress tests on Thursday, despite losses of $526 billion forecast in the central bank's most dire economic scenario.Investors will now turn their attention to the second round of stress-test results, which the Fed releases Wednesday. Wall Street tends to focus more on that round, as the Fed determines whether the banks' requests for bigger dividends and stock buybacks are reasonable given the impact the firms would sustain under the test scenarios.The Fed said the 33 banks tested this year would sustain $385 billion in loan losses under the 2016 test circumstances, which include a sharp drop in housing prices, 10% unemployment and negative rates on short-term U.S. Treasuries, a notable difference from the tests last year. Consumer loans accounted for 52% of forecast loan losses among the banks, the Fed said.The Fed also noted that its hypothetical conditions were softer on investment banks' profits, but that the negative short-term interest rates were harder hit by the negative rates."As compared to last year's severely adverse scenario, firms that are active in trading and market activities saw smaller losses in net income as a result of less severe stress in the equity markets, but firms more focused on traditional lending activities were more affected by negative short-term interest rates and greater stress in the real economy," the Fed said.Analysts largely expected the banks to get through the first round unscathed, although the Fed could still reject their capital plans next week.Among major banks, Citi came out with the highest Tier 1 common capital ratio -- a way of quantifying banks' most durable assets and the most-watched metric for the tests -- at a 9.2% minimum in the Fed's darkest scenario. Morgan Stanley had 9.1%, Goldman Sachs 8.4%, JPMorgan 8.3%, BofA 8.1% and Wells Fargo 7.2%. The Fed requires at least 5% to pass.Huntington Bancshares (HBAN) came closest to falling short, with a ratio of 5%.JPMorgan rose 1% after hours on the stock market today, Bank of America added 1.7% and Citigroup gained 2.7%, and Wells Fargo edged up 0.6%. Investment banks Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, seen as potentially more vulnerable to recent market swings, were up 0.8% and 0.9%, respectively.The Fed first posed the economic scenario to the 33 banks in January. Banks responded with their stress-test results and capital-return plans in April."Today's results have reaffirmed what we already knew — U.S. banks are strongly capitalized and remain well-positioned to serve as a critical economic driver going forward," American Bankers Association CEO Rob Nichols said in a statement following the release of the stress-test results."Even under the worst imaginable conditions, banks' strong capital positions and solid balance sheets would allow them to continue lending and meeting the needs of their clients, customers and communities."

All but three of the 31 big banks examined by the Federal Reserve won approval of any plans to return capital to investors in the second round of annual stress tests. In other words: more payouts for shareholders.

The U.S. units of Spain's Banco Santander (SAN) and Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) failed round 2 of the Fed's stress tests, while the Fed ordered Bank of America  (BAC) to resubmit its capital plan by the end of the third quarter.
It's the second straight year Santander failed the test. And the Fed cited "numerous and significant deficiencies" in Deutsche Bank's capital planning.
Meanwhile, Wells Fargo (WFC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) boosted their dividends and Morgan approved a new buyback plan, joining other banks that received the Fed's OK of their capital plans.
Shares of BofA fell 1% late, while Morgan Stanley rose 2% and Wells Fargo edged up 0.1%.

The second round of the exams — the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) — is more stringent than round one, the Dodd-Frank Act Stress Tests (DFAST), because it examines banks' abilities to pay dividends, buy back shares and still serve borrowers during times of severe economic distress.

This year, the Fed examined 31 banks, each with assets exceeding $50 billion. All 31 banks passed DFAST last week, which means they met the Fed's minimum capital requirements. It was the first time they all passed since the test's 2009 inception.
A More Likely Place To Trip

Round 2 is where banks are more likely to stumble. Michael Corbat, the CEO of Citigroup (C), should be breathing easier, since the New York-based lender passed this year's tests after failing two out of the last three years. Last year's failure resulted in Citi's selling overseas branches as well as selling its consumer finance unit, OneMain Financial, for $4.25 billion.

This is the first year Citigroup will be able to boost its dividend since the financial crisis. Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach's jobs reportedly were on the line during this year's stress tests. Citi's passage comes as a big win for them. Citi shares rose 3.7% in after-hours trading.
HSBC (HSBC) and Zions Bancorp (ZION) failed last year's CCAR but passed this year's exam.
Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Morgan Stanley met minimum capital requirements on a post-test basis after submitting adjustments.

"This is becoming less and less an adversarial process between the organizations," said Ernest Patrikis, a former New York Fed official now with the White & Case law firm. "I think for the banking system as a whole, we should feel a bit better."
Musing Over Board Control

While CCAR has become the key test of banks' health since the Great Recession, Patrikis said he'd like to see the day when a bank's board — not the Fed — again has the power to return money to owners. "Banks should be allowed to have more freedom to raise dividends," he said.

Shares of regional banks PNC Financial Services Group (PNC) and BB&T (BBT) went in different directions on the stock market, even though both companies topped quarterly profit views.

Pittsburgh-based PNC, the nation's second-biggest regional bank behind US Bancorp (USB), reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.85 a share, up 8% from the previous year and 20 cents above consensus estimates.
Revenue was virtually flat at $4.07 billion but well above the $3.83 billion consensus.
Shares rose 3% to the highest in more than five years.

PNC's bottom line got a boost from a 10% decrease in noninterest expenses as the bank slashed its mortgage workforce and closed or consolidated 16 branches during the quarter. It wound up closing a total of 186 branches in 2013 as part of an overall strategy to cut costs.

"PNC has a strong balance sheet, along with a clear set of strategic priorities, that position us to continue to deliver for all of our constituencies even as the economic and regulatory climates continue to evolve," Chief Executive William Demchak said in a statement.

BB&T, the No. 3 U.S. regional bank, earned 72 cents a share, up a penny from a year earlier and a penny above analysts' estimates. Revenue declined 6% to $2.38 billion, just topping views of $2.37 billion.

But the company's net interest margin, which measures the spread between the average yield on loans and investments and the average cost for deposits and borrowings, fell to a tax-adjusted 3.56% from 3.68% the prior quarter and 3.84% the previous year.
BB&T shares fell 1%, a day after hitting their highest level since September 2008.

Another regional bank, Columbus, Ohio-based Huntington Bancshares (HBAN), saw its stock drop 4% Thursday after it reported a Q4 earnings dipped to 18 cents a share from 19 cents the prior year but still a penny above estimates.

Huntington's revenue fell 6% to $685.5 million, above views for $680.8 million. This shows us how much investors are willing to pay for each dollar of earnings in a given stock, and is easily one of the most popular financial ratios in the world. The best use of the PE ratio is to compare the stock’s current PE ratio with: a) where this ratio has been in the past; b) how it compares to the average for the industry/sector; and c) how it compares to the market as a whole.On this front, Huntington has a trailing twelve months PE ratio of 15, as you can see in the chart below:This level actually compares pretty favorably with the market at large, as the PE for the S&P 500 stands at about 21.3. Stagnant companies may generate near-term profit but do not ensure enough growth to attract new investors.Without solid top-line growth, bottom-line improvement may not be sustainable over the longer term. While a company can show earnings strength by reducing expenses, a sustainable bottom-line recovery usually requires robust sales growth.However, sales growth in isolation doesn’t indicate much about a company’s future performance. Though it provides investors an insight into product demand and pricing power, a huge sales number is not necessarily translated into profits.Therefore, taking into consideration a company’s cash position along with its sales number can prove to be a more dependable strategy.
